column2: He never found out who this kind man was; perhaps one of the peasant witnesses, or Nikolay Parfenovitch's little secretary, had compassionately thought to put a pillow under his head; but his whole soul was quivering with tears.

column2: He went to the table and said that he would sign whatever they liked.
column3: He went to the table and said that he would sign whatever they liked.

column2: They Carry Mitya Away

column2: When the protocol had been signed, Nikolay Parfenovitch turned solemnly to the prisoner and read him the "Committal," setting forth, that in such a year, on such a day, in such a place, the investigating lawyer of such-and-such a district court, having examined so-and-so (to wit, Mitya) accused of this and of that (all the charges were carefully written out) and having considered that the accused, not pleading guilty to the charges made against him, had brought forward nothing in his defense, while the witnesses, so-and-so, and so-and-so, and the circumstances such-and-such testify against him, acting in accordance with such-and-such articles of the Statute Book, and so on, has ruled, that, in order to preclude so-and-so (Mitya) from all means of evading pursuit and judgment he be detained in such-and-such a prison, which he hereby notifies to the accused and communicates a copy of this same "Committal" to the deputy prosecutor, and so on, and so on.

column2: In brief, Mitya was informed that he was, from that moment, a prisoner, and that he would be driven at once to the town, and there shut up in a very unpleasant place.
column3: In brief, Mitya was informed that he was, from that moment, a prisoner, and that he would be driven at once to the town, and there shut up in a very unpleasant place.

column2: Mitya listened attentively, and only shrugged his shoulders.

column2: I'm ready....

column2: I understand that there's nothing else for you to do."

column2: Stay, Mitya interrupted, suddenly, and impelled by uncontrollable feeling he pronounced, addressing all in the room:
column3: Stay, Mitya interrupted, suddenly, and impelled by uncontrollable feeling he pronounced, addressing all in the room:

column2: Gentlemen, we're all cruel, we're all monsters, we all make men weep, and mothers, and babes at the breast, but of all, let it be settled here, now, of all I am the lowest reptile!	Gentlemen, we're all cruel, we're all monsters, we all make men weep, and mothers, and babes at the breast, but of all, let it be settled here, now, of all I am the lowest reptile!

column2: I've sworn to amend, and every day I've done the same filthy things.
column3: I've sworn to amend, and every day I've done the same filthy things.

column2: I understand now that such men as I need a blow, a blow of destiny to catch them as with a noose, and bind them by a force from without.
column3: I understand now that such men as I need a blow, a blow of destiny to catch them as with a noose, and bind them by a force from without.

column2: Never, never should I have risen of myself!
column3: Never, never should I have risen of myself!

column2: But the thunderbolt has fallen.
column3: But the thunderbolt has fallen.

column2: I accept the torture of accusation, and my public shame, I want to suffer and by suffering I shall be purified.
column3: I accept the torture of accusation, and my public shame, I want to suffer and by suffering I shall be purified.

column2: Perhaps I shall be purified, gentlemen?
column3: Perhaps I shall be purified, gentlemen?

column2: But listen, for the last time, I am not guilty of my father's blood.
column3: But listen, for the last time, I am not guilty of my father's blood.

column2: I accept my punishment, not because I killed him, but because I meant to kill him, and perhaps I really might have killed him.
column3: I accept my punishment, not because I killed him, but because I meant to kill him, and perhaps I really might have killed him.

column2: Still I mean to fight it out with you.
column3: Still I mean to fight it out with you.

column2: I warn you of that. I'll fight it out with you to the end, and then God will decide.
column3: I warn you of that. I'll fight it out with you to the end, and then God will decide.

column2: Good-by, gentlemen, don't be vexed with me for having shouted at you during the examination.
column3: Good by, gentlemen, don't be vexed with me for having shouted at you during the examination.

column2: Oh, I was still such a fool then....
column3: Oh, I was still such a fool then....

column2: In another minute I shall be a prisoner, but now, for the last time, as a free man, Dmitri Karamazov offers you his hand.
column3: In another minute I shall be a prisoner, but now, for the last time, as a free man, Dmitri Karamazov offers you his hand.

column2: Saying good-by to you, I say it to all men."
column3: Saying good by to you, I say it to all men."

column2: His voice quivered and he stretched out his hand, but Nikolay Parfenovitch, who happened to stand nearest to him, with a sudden, almost nervous movement, hid his hands behind his back.
column3: His voice quivered and he stretched out his hand, but Nikolay Parfenovitch, who happened to stand nearest to him, with a sudden, almost nervous movement, hid his hands behind his back.

column2: He let his outstretched hand fall at once.

column2: I will follow you for ever, wherever they may send you.

column2: Farewell; you are guiltless, though you've been your own undoing."
